Intro.0: A new technique that leverages Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) could allow attackers to bypass security solutions installed in the user’s system.
Intro.1: A newly-disclosed Windows SMB zero-day vulnerability, could remotely cause a denial of service (DoS) on  a vulnerable system.
Intro.2: It was only a matter of time until cybercriminals would find a way to abuse the popular game, Pokemon Go and create a Pokemon Go-themed ransomware.
Intro.3: Cerber, a cypto-ransomware variant that made the rounds in early March this year, has been discovered using email as another way to distribute the malware,
Intro.4: “Windows 9 Free Download!“ sounds too good to be true but cybercriminals still use bait like this to get you to install adware on your computer.
Intro.5: Like a thousand ways to skin a cat, there are a number of ways malware avoid detection. POWELIKS malware, for example, hides in the Windows registry. Trend Micro analyzes its behavior and makes sure that customers are safe from this malware.
Intro.6: Recent targeted attacks that send bogus emails from a Chinese newspaper were found targeting systems with Windows PowerShell installed. The PowerShell command line is typically found on Windows 7 onwards and is used to automate Windows applications.
Intro.7: RATs or remote access Trojans—like the prominent Gh0st, PoisonIvy, and DRAT—have made it easier for attackers to stay hidden within a target network. A RAT's ability to disguise their network traffic as messaging app traffic makes it especially elusive.
Intro.8: Several flaws at risk of being exploited, including ones disclosed by Shadow Brokers, have been patched by Microsoft in Windows XP and other older versions of the OS  [Read More]
Intro.9: Cyberespionage group apparently not linked to any previously known actor uses Windows and Android malware to target organizations in the Middle East  [Read More]
Intro.10: Microsoft has become aware of targeted cyberattacks leveraging a new vulnerability (CVE-2014-6352) that affects most supported Windows releases.  [Read More]
Intro.11: Attackers exploited a zero-day vulnerability in Windows to spy on NATO, the European Union, the Ukraine, and private energy and telecommunications companies, according to cyber-intelligence firm iSight Partners.  [Read More]
Intro.12: Cybercriminals have been serving malicious advertisements on several high-profile websites in an effort to push shady software onto the computers of their visitors, regardless if they are Windows or OS X users, Cisco reported on Monday.  [Read More]
Intro.13: Focused on mining Monero crypto-currency, a new botnet has managed to ensnare over half a million machines to date, most of which are believed to be servers.  [Read More]
Intro.14: A new Windows 10 feature that makes the popular Linux bash terminal available for Microsoft’s operating system could allow for more malware families to target the operating system, Check Point researchers claim.  [Read More]
Intro.15: A new Windows backdoor was apparently created by the same cybercriminals who used the SambaCry exploit to deliver a cryptocurrency miner  [Read More]
Intro.16: Windows Defender ATP in Windows 10 Creators Update can detect code injection techniques associated with these threats, such as process hollowing and atom bombing.  [Read More]
Intro.17: Most of the computers affected by the WannaCry ransomware outbreak were running Windows 7, security researchers have revealed.  [Read More]
Intro.18: Cybercriminals have been using a macro-enabled Word document that can be used to infect both macOS and Windows machines with malware.  [Read More]
Intro.19: Windows 10 could soon allow users to block the installation of applications coming from other sources than the Microsoft Store, a feature that would likely help prevent the installation of malware.  [Read More]
Intro.20: The Windows variant of the infamous Mirai Linux botnet is the offspring of a more experienced bot herder, possibly of Chinese origin, Kaspersky Lab security researchers warn.  [Read More]
Intro.21: A new Windows variant of Mirai is written in C++ and appears capable of performing various nefarious operations, one of which involves the spreading of the Mirai botnet to Linux-based devices.  [Read More]
Intro.22: A highly obfuscated malicious backdoor that has been infecting organizations worldwide since 2013 was recently observed abusing the Windows Troubleshooting Platform (WTP) feature for distribution.  [Read More]
Intro.23: New Locky ransomware attacks aimed at companies leverage Windows script files to evade detection.  [Read More]
Intro.24: Researchers at SecureWorks warn that a lesser-known capability in Background Intelligent Transfer Service (BITS) is being leveraged to download malware.  [Read More]
Intro.25: Newly observed "Furtim" malware goes through great lengths to avoid being caught by security parties: it includes checks for 400 security products.  [Read More]
Intro.26: Researchers from Intel Security discovered a piece of malware dubbed "Dynamer" that is taking advantage of a Windows Easter Egg called “God Mode” to gain persistency on an infected machine.  [Read More]
Intro.27: A new Gozi Trojan build has been observed in the wild, modified to inject malicious code into Windows 10’s Edge browser, IBM X-Force researchers warn.  [Read More]
Intro.28: Researchers at Kaspersky Lab have discovered a Linux backdoor that has been migrated to Windows and added a series of new capabilities.  [Read More]
Intro.29: A new variant of the Dyre banking Trojan includes support for Windows 10 and the Microsoft Edge browser.  [Read More]
Intro.30: Beware of fake Windows 10 upgrade emails! They carry a piece of ransomware that encrypts your files.  [Read More]
Intro.31: Researchers at Kaspersky have conducted a detailed analysis of some of the plugins used by the advanced persistent threat (APT) group known as BlackEnergy2 (BE2), or Sandworm Team.  [Read More]
Intro.32: The Vawtrak banking malware now leverages macros and the Windows PowerShell scripting tool to infect computers, Trend Micro reported on Monday.  [Read More]
Intro.33: Researchers have identified an older variant of the recently uncovered WireLurker OS X/iOS malware which appears to have been designed to target computers running Microsoft Windows.  [Read More]
Intro.34: A Windows backdoor used in numerous attacks by a certain threat group has been ported to Mac OS X and fitted with new features, researchers at FireEye reported.  [Read More]
Intro.35: Security researchers have discovered that a piece of malware designed to run on Linux computers has been ported by its creators to Windows.  [Read More]
Intro.36: Researchers at Trend Micro have analyzed a new Trojan that uses the Windows registry to hide all it's malicious code.  [Read More]
Intro.37: Windows PowerShell is being increasingly used by malicious actors not only for data theft, but also for ransomware attacks, researchers have warned.  [Read More]
Intro.38: Researchers from Kaspersky Lab have uncovered a new malware that has the ability to infect systems running Windows, Mac OS X, and Linux and launch DDoS attacks from any infected devices.  [Read More]
Intro.39: Microsoft said on Wednesday that it would help customers as they migrate to newer versions of the Windows operating system by extending support to the platform’s antimalware features.  [Read More]
Intro.40: The vulnerability is being used in conjunction with an Adobe Reader exploit to infect Windows computers.  [Read More]
Intro.41: Bit9 has launched a free tool that scans for executable files (dll, installer, script and other programs) on Windows-based systems to help users detect potentially malicious files and areas of risk on their PCs.  [Read More]
Intro.42: vSkimmer targets payment card terminals connected to Windows systems and appears to be the successor to Dexter financial malware.  [Read More]
Intro.43: Researchers at ESET have discovered a Trojan that initially focused on Windows users, but appears to be changing direction and now targeting Mac OS X users.  [Read More]
Intro.44: Windows 8 was found to be just as vulnerable to common malware as Windows 7, despite the compensating controls being pitched by the company.  [Read More]
Intro.45: The password hints saved in Windows 7 and Windows 8 can be retrieved and decoded by attackers, two researchers have found.  [Read More]
Intro.46: If allowed to run, a malicious Java applet checks the user's operating system and delivers a payload customized for that platform, whether it's Windows, Mac OS X, or Linux.  [Read More]
Intro.47: According to new information revealed by researchers, three modules of the malware – named Snack, Gadget and Munch – are used to launch what is essentially a man-in-the-middle attack against other computers on a network.  [Read More]
Intro.48: Austrian security analyst Peter Kleisnner is slated to unveil the first known bootkit for Windows 8 at the upcoming MalCon security conference in Mumbai.  [Read More]
Intro.49: Taking another page from Stuxnet, it seems the attackers behind Duqu used a Microsoft Windows zero-day as part of their attack campaign.  [Read More]
Intro.50: The specter of advanced persistent threats (APTs) hangs over a growing number of conversations these days about enterprise security, and has prompted businesses to take a closer look at how they can make their environments less vulnerable. For some, this has reignited discussions about how the security of Apple’s Mac OS X stacks up against Microsoft Windows.  [Read More]
Intro.51: Windows Defender Advanced Threat Protection (Windows Defender ATP) is capable of detecting behavior associated with the sophisticated FinFisher spyware used by law enforcement agencies.  [Read More]
Intro.52: Wikileaks as published documents detailing AngelFire, a tool allegedly used by the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) to load and execute implants on Windows-based systems.  [Read More]
Intro.53: Microsoft said it would maintain efforts to gain approval in China for its Windows 8 operating system after a ban announced by Beijing.  [Read More]
Intro.54: Windows 10 has just been released and with all highly-anticipated product releases, cybercriminals are already taking advantage of the hype. Recently our engineers here at Trendlabs spotted a spam mail making the rounds, one pretending to be an email notification for a free update of Microsoft's latest OS.Read more
Intro.55: Despite being released in 2001, Windows XP remains a popular OS for users. According to reports, the OS still has around 30% of the user market share.Read more
Intro.56: New releases, be it software or hardware, are the most usual jump off points where cybercriminals launch their attacks. The October 2012 Windows 8 release is one of the new releases that cybercriminals used as lure.Read more
Intro.57: TrendLabs engineers found spammers using Yahoo! and Windows Live as bait for users. The spammed messages bear the subject, CONGRATULATION! CONGRATULATION!! CONGRATULATION!!! to entice users to open the attached .Read more
Intro.58: BoundHook hooking method is invisible to Windows 10’s PatchGuard. The issue is not considered a vulnerability by Microsoft  [Read More]
Intro.59: Microsoft patches critical remote code execution flaw in Windows that hackers can exploit without user interaction via malicious DNS responses  [Read More]
Intro.60: Microsoft patches 48 vulnerabilities, including a Windows Search flaw that has been actively exploited in attacks  [Read More]
Intro.61: Siemens warns customers that some of its medical imaging products are exposed to attacks due to Windows vulnerabilities exploited in the wild  [Read More]
Intro.62: An old Kerberos authentication bypass vulnerability dubbed Orpheus' Lyre has been patched in Windows and some Linux distributions  [Read More]
Intro.63: Google researchers find remote code execution vulnerability in Windows. Flaw described as “worst,” “crazy bad” and “wormable”  [Read More]
Intro.64: WikiLeaks publishes documents detailing Grasshopper, a platform used by CIA to create Windows malware installers  [Read More]
Intro.65: Researchers have found a way to bypass Microsoft EMET mitigations with one shot via the WoW64 Windows subsystem.  [Read More]
Intro.66: A recent security bulletin released by Microsoft as part of the August 2014 Patch Tuesday can lead to a crash on some systems, the company said in a knowledge base article.  [Read More]
Intro.67: Microsoft releases out-of-band update for Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 to address a serious vulnerability introduced by Meltdown patches  [Read More]
Intro.68: Microsoft’s updates for the Meltdown and Spectre CPU vulnerabilities break Windows on some AMD computers. Patches also cause problems for some apps  [Read More]
Intro.69: An update released by Webroot caused the company’s antivirus to detect legitimate files as W32.Trojan.Gen  [Read More]
Intro.70: Google's Android platform was used on four out of five smartphones sold worldwide in the third quarter, while Microsoft's Windows Phone showed strong gains, according to IDC.  [Read More]
Intro.71: The PhoneFactor App for Windows Phone extends the PhoneFactor platform to include another option for securely authenticating access to both on-premises and cloud applications using the phone a person already carries.  [Read More]
Intro.72: Mobile security firm, NQ Mobile, today announced that former Microsoft executive, Gavin Kim, has joined the company as Chief Product Officer.  [Read More]
Intro.73: Google researcher Tavis Ormandy releases tool for porting Windows DLLs to Linux to improve fuzzing - ports Windows Defender as demo  [Read More]
Intro.74: A zero-day vulnerability impacting Telegram Messenger’s Windows client had been exploited in malicious attacks for months before being discovered and addressed.  [Read More]
Intro.75: The upcoming Windows 10 Fall Creators Update will bring enhanced privacy controls to both consumers and commercial customers, Microsoft says.  [Read More]
Intro.76: Windows 10 users who haven’t installed the Creators Update will soon be notified to review their privacy settings and to install the latest feature update to remain secure, Microsoft announced.  [Read More]
Intro.77: Some say Microsoft has been overly aggressive in pushing Windows 10 on existing Windows users, and being accused of being fast and loose with user privacy.  [Read More]
Intro.78: Microsoft on published new details on the user data collection in Windows 10, in an attempt to put controversy on the matter to rest.  [Read More]
Intro.79: Microsoft has pushed its Diagnostics and Telemetry tracking service to existing in-use Windows 7 and Windows 8 devices in an effort to collect more data on them.  [Read More]
Intro.80: Microsoft announces Windows bug bounty program with payouts ranging between $500 and $250,000  [Read More]
Intro.81: Microsoft rolled out the options for customers to enable multi-factor authentication its Windows Azure cloud service.  [Read More]
Intro.82: Barracuda Networks has teamed up with Microsoft to bring additional levels of protection to web applications and data hosted in Microsoft’s Windows Azure cloud.  [Read More]
Intro.83: Face authentication system present in Windows Hello tricked by researchers using a printed photo  [Read More]
Intro.84: A newly technique that leverages App Paths to bypass the User Account Control (UAC) in Windows 10 has been detailed by security researcher Matt Nelson.  [Read More]
Intro.85: An issue affecting Microsoft’s Windows operating system could result in leaked user credentials if Internet Explorer and Edge are being used, researchers discovered.  [Read More]
Intro.86: The "Re-Direct to SMB" vulnerability impacts all versions of Windows, including the upcoming Windows 10, as well as products from major software makers such as Adobe, Apple, Oracle, and Symantec.  [Read More]
Intro.87: The new Windows 10 operating system will allow users to sign in to a device without a password by using biometrics, including facial recognition.  [Read More]
Intro.88: The Kerberos authentication protocol enables a disabled user account to remain valid for up to 10 hours after having been revoked, researchers say.  [Read More]
Intro.89: Windows 10 Anniversary update includes Windows Information Protection (WIP), a feature meant to keep user’s information safe even when data leaks occur.  [Read More]
Intro.90: Windows 10 devices have built-in disk encryption that is turned on out of the box, offering additional data protection, but the recovery keys are automatically copied to Microsoft servers when users login using their Microsoft accounts.  [Read More]
Intro.91: A sleep feature in Microsoft Windows may significantly reduce security of full disk encryption, Passware warned today.  [Read More]
Intro.92: Microsoft researchers release SAMRi10, a new anti-reconnaissance tool for Windows 10 and Windows Server 2016  [Read More]
Intro.93: Attackers are exploiting a recently disclosed zero-day vulnerability in Internet Explorer in campaigns targeting Windows XP users. While the vulnerability was patched by Microsoft in an Out-of-Band release on Thursday, security researchers have discovered a series of attacks targeting various industries.  [Read More]
Intro.94: A recently disclosed User Account Control (UAC) bypass that leverages App Paths can be used for fileless attacks as well, security researcher Matt Nelson now says.  [Read More]
Intro.95: Researchers once again bypass the User Account Control (UAC) security feature in Windows – this time they used the Event Viewer  [Read More]
Intro.96: Microsoft has started distributing some of Intel’s microcode patches for the Spectre vulnerability to Windows users  [Read More]
